item.title: Active Inference with Reusable State-Dependent Value Profiles
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: adaptive behavior, value profiles, belief-weighted mixing, probabilistic reversal learning, policy priors

Summary: 1. The article addresses how agents adapt behavior in volatile environments by switching control strategies based on latent contexts, which is usually computationally intractable if separate parameters are maintained for every context. 2. A novel concept called value profiles is introduced, which bundles outcome preferences, policy priors, and policy precision into reusable parameter sets linked to hidden states in a generative model. 3. As beliefs over latent states update trial by trial, control parameters emerge through a belief-weighted mixture of these profiles, enabling flexible state-conditional strategy use without an explosion in parameter complexity. 4. The authors evaluate their approach against simpler static-precision and entropy-coupled dynamic-precision models in a probabilistic reversal learning task, finding strong model superiority via cross-validated log-likelihood and information criteria (around 100-point AIC advantages). 5. Parameter recovery supports structural identifiability even with noisy observations and inferred contexts, indicating robustness. Model-based inference reveals adaptive control is primarily driven by modulation of policy priors rather than changes in policy precision, with gradual recruitment of profiles reflecting belief-dependent, state-conditional control rather than merely responding to uncertainty. 6. Overall, value profiles offer a computationally tractable framework for belief-conditioned value control in volatile environments and furnish testable predictions related to flexible behavioral adaptation.
arXiv:2512.11829v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Adaptive behavior in volatile environments requires agents to switch among value-control regimes across latent contexts, but maintaining separate preferences, policy biases, and action-confidence parameters for every situation is intractable. We introduce value profiles: a small set of reusable bundles of value-related parameters (outcome preferences, policy priors, and policy precision) assigned to hidden states in a generative model. As posterior beliefs over states evolve trial by trial, effective control parameters arise via belief-weighted mixing, enabling state-conditional strategy recruitment without requiring independent parameters for each context. We evaluate this framework in probabilistic reversal learning, comparing static-precision, entropy-coupled dynamic-precision, and profile-based models using cross-validated log-likelihood and information criteria. Model comparison favors the profile-based model over simpler alternatives (about 100-point AIC differences), and parameter-recovery analyses support structural identifiability even when context must be inferred from noisy observations. Model-based inference further suggests that adaptive control in this task is driven primarily by modulation of policy priors rather than policy precision, with gradual belief-dependent profile recruitment consistent with state-conditional (not purely uncertainty-driven) control. Overall, reusable value profiles provide a tractable computational account of belief-conditioned value control in volatile environments and yield testable signatures of belief-dependent control and behavioral flexibility.

item.title: CR3G: Causal Reasoning for Patient-Centric Explanations in Radiology Report Generation
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: chest X-ray, causal inference, AI diagnostics, report generation, patient-centric explanation

Summary: 1. The paper addresses the challenge of automatic chest X-ray report generation, a critical task for improving diagnostic accuracy and aiding faster clinical decisions. 2. While current AI models excel at identifying patterns in medical images, they often fail to capture deeper cause-and-effect relationships that clarify why certain X-ray findings correspond to specific diagnoses. 3. The authors propose a novel prompt-driven framework called Causal Reasoning for Patient-Centric Explanations in radiology Report Generation (CR3G). This framework focuses on causal inference to enhance the interpretability of AI-generated reports by incorporating reasoning about cause-and-effect relationships. 4. CR3G emphasizes generating explanations centered on the patient, aiming to make AI diagnostics more meaningful, trustworthy, and useful in clinical practice. 5. Experimental results demonstrate that CR3G improves the ability to identify causal relationships and provides better explanations for 2 out of 5 tested abnormalities, indicating its potential to advance the quality of AI-driven chest X-ray diagnostics.
arXiv:2512.11830v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Automatic chest X-ray report generation is an important area of research aimed at improving diagnostic accuracy and helping doctors make faster decisions. Current AI models are good at finding correlations (or patterns) in medical images. Still, they often struggle to understand the deeper cause-and-effect relationships between those patterns and a patient condition. Causal inference is a powerful approach that goes beyond identifying patterns to uncover why certain findings in an X-ray relate to a specific diagnosis. In this paper, we will explore the prompt-driven framework Causal Reasoning for Patient-Centric Explanations in radiology Report Generation (CR3G) that is applied to chest X-ray analysis to improve understanding of AI-generated reports by focusing on cause-and-effect relationships, reasoning and generate patient-centric explanation. The aim to enhance the quality of AI-driven diagnostics, making them more useful and trustworthy in clinical practice. CR3G has shown better causal relationship capability and explanation capability for 2 out of 5 abnormalities.

item.title: On the Design of One-step Diffusion via Shortcutting Flow Paths
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: few-step diffusion models, shortcut models, one-step diffusion, ImageNet-256x256, classifier-free guidance

Summary: This paper addresses the challenges in few-step diffusion models, focusing on shortcut models that train one-step diffusion models directly from scratch. The authors highlight that previous approaches often intertwine theoretical derivations with practical implementations, which limits understanding and restricts design flexibility. To overcome this, they introduce a common design framework that unifies representative shortcut models by providing solid theoretical grounding while separating individual component choices. This disentanglement enables systematic innovation at the component level, aiding researchers in improving model performance more methodically. Leveraging these improvements, their newly designed one-step diffusion model achieves a state-of-the-art Fréchet Inception Distance (FID50k) score of 2.85 on the ImageNet-256x256 dataset under classifier-free guidance, demonstrating superior image generation quality. Importantly, their approach eliminates the need for pre-training, knowledge distillation, or curriculum learning, simplifying the training pipeline. Overall, the work lowers barriers to experimenting with shortcut diffusion models by clarifying the design space, thus fostering principled exploration and accelerating future advancements in efficient diffusion modeling.
arXiv:2512.11831v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent advances in few-step diffusion models have demonstrated their efficiency and effectiveness by shortcutting the probabilistic paths of diffusion models, especially in training one-step diffusion models from scratch (a.k.a. shortcut models). However, their theoretical derivation and practical implementation are often closely coupled, which obscures the design space. To address this, we propose a common design framework for representative shortcut models. This framework provides theoretical justification for their validity and disentangles concrete component-level choices, thereby enabling systematic identification of improvements. With our proposed improvements, the resulting one-step model achieves a new state-of-the-art FID50k of 2.85 on ImageNet-256x256 under the classifier-free guidance setting. Remarkably, the model requires no pre-training, distillation, or curriculum learning. We believe our work lowers the barrier to component-level innovation in shortcut models and facilitates principled exploration of their design space.

item.title: Performance and Efficiency of Climate In-Situ Data Reconstruction: Why Optimized IDW Outperforms kriging and Implicit Neural Representation
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: sparse climate data, inverse distance weighting, ordinary kriging, implicit neural representation, reconstruction accuracy

Summary: This study compares three reconstruction methods for sparse climate data: inverse distance weighting (IDW), ordinary kriging (OK), and an implicit neural representation model based on the MMGN architecture. Each method was optimized through hyper-parameter tuning using validation data to ensure fair evaluation. Extensive experiments were performed on 100 randomly sampled sparse datasets from the ECA&D database, followed by comprehensive statistical analyses. Results showed that the simple IDW method outperformed both OK and MMGN in terms of reconstruction accuracy and computational efficiency. IDW achieved the lowest error values, with an RMSE of 3.00 ± 1.93, MAE of 1.32 ± 0.77, and maximum deviation (ΔMAX) of 24.06 ± 17.15. It also had the highest coefficient of determination, R² at 0.68 ± 0.16. Statistical testing confirmed that the differences in RMSE, MAE, and R² were significant and exhibited moderate to large effect sizes, highlighting the reliable advantage of IDW. The Dunn post-hoc test further verified that IDW consistently surpassed the other methods across all quality metrics evaluated. These findings suggest that despite its simplicity, IDW is highly effective for reconstructing sparse climate datasets.
arXiv:2512.11832v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This study evaluates three reconstruction methods for sparse climate data: the simple inverse distance weighting (IDW), the statistically grounded ordinary kriging (OK), and the advanced implicit neural representation model (MMGN architecture). All methods were optimized through hyper-parameter tuning using validation splits. An extensive set of experiments was conducted, followed by a comprehensive statistical analysis. The results demonstrate the superiority of the simple IDW method over the other reference methods in terms of both reconstruction accuracy and computational efficiency. IDW achieved the lowest RMSE ($3.00 \pm 1.93$), MAE ($1.32 \pm 0.77$), and $\Delta_{MAX}$ ($24.06 \pm 17.15$), as well as the highest $R^2$ ($0.68 \pm 0.16$), across 100 randomly sampled sparse datasets from the ECA\&D database. Differences in RMSE, MAE, and $R^2$ were statistically significant and exhibited moderate to large effect sizes. The Dunn post-hoc test further confirmed the consistent superiority of IDW across all evaluated quality measures [...]

item.title: Soft Decision Tree classifier: explainable and extendable PyTorch implementation
item.content:encoded:
Soft Decision Tree, Short-term Memory, Explainability, Clinical Datasets, Classification Methods

Summary:

This paper presents the implementation of a Soft Decision Tree (SDT) and a Short-term Memory Soft Decision Tree (SM-SDT) using the PyTorch framework. Both models were evaluated extensively on simulated data as well as real clinical datasets to assess their performance. The authors provided visualizations of the SDT to highlight its potential for explainability, an important feature for decision-making processes in healthcare. The comparison of classification methods included SDT, SM-SDT, XGBoost, Random Forest, Logistic Regression, and a traditional Decision Tree. The results showed that SDT, SM-SDT, and XGBoost achieved similar area under the curve (AUC) values, indicating comparable predictive performance. These three methods outperformed Random Forest, Logistic Regression, and Decision Tree classifiers. The findings also suggest that aside from the standard decision tree, all other tested methods delivered comparable results on clinical datasets. The paper emphasizes the balance between model explainability and predictive accuracy. Additionally, the authors have made their code and datasets publicly available on GitHub, encouraging transparency and reproducibility of their work. This contribution supports the development of interpretable machine learning models for clinical applications.
arXiv:2512.11833v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We implemented a Soft Decision Tree (SDT) and a Short-term Memory Soft Decision Tree (SM-SDT) using PyTorch. The methods were extensively tested on simulated and clinical datasets. The SDT was visualized to demonstrate the potential for its explainability. SDT, SM-SDT, and XGBoost demonstrated similar area under the curve (AUC) values. These methods were better than Random Forest, Logistic Regression, and Decision Tree. The results on clinical datasets suggest that, aside from a decision tree, all tested classification methods yield comparable results. The code and datasets are available online on GitHub: https://github.com/KI-Research-Institute/Soft-Decision-Tree

item.title: Hybrid twinning using PBDW and DeepONet for the effective state estimation and prediction on partially known systems
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: state estimation, hybrid approach, Parameterized Background Data-Weak, Deep Operator Network, Helmholtz equation

Summary: The paper addresses the challenge of accurately estimating the state of complex and uncertain physical systems by integrating theoretical models and noisy experimental data. It proposes a hybrid method that combines physics-based modeling with data-driven learning to improve state estimation and prediction accuracy. The approach extends the Parameterized Background Data-Weak (PBDW) framework, which fuses a reduced-order model representation with measurement data to handle both known and unknown uncertainties. To capture discrepancies not represented by the reduced-order model, a Deep Operator Network (DeepONet) is introduced. This DeepONet is constrained to lie within the orthogonal complement of the best-knowledge model manifold, ensuring that the learned corrections target only the unmodeled bias components, thereby maintaining model interpretability and fidelity. The study also explores an optimal sensor placement strategy to maximize information gain from measurements, enhancing state estimation quality. Validation is performed using a test problem involving the Helmholtz equation that simulates various model errors, including those from boundary conditions and source terms. The results demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed hybrid framework in addressing uncertainties and improving state estimation in complex physical systems.
arXiv:2512.11834v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The accurate estimation of the state of complex uncertain physical systems requires reconciling theoretical models, with inherent imperfections, with noisy experimental data. In this work, we propose an effective hybrid approach that combines physics-based modeling with data-driven learning to enhance state estimation and further prediction. Our method builds upon the Parameterized Background Data-Weak (PBDW) framework, which naturally integrates a reduced-order representation of the best-available model with measurement data to account for both anticipated and unanticipated uncertainties. To address model discrepancies not captured by the reduced-order space, and learn the structure of model deviation, we incorporate a Deep Operator Network (DeepONet) constrained to be an orthogonal complement of the best-knowledge manifold. This ensures that the learned correction targets only the unknown components of model bias, preserving the interpretability and fidelity of the physical model. An optimal sensor placement strategy is also investigated to maximize information gained from measurements. We validate the proposed approach on a representative problem involving the Helmholtz equation under various sources of modeling error, including those arising from boundary conditions and source terms.

item.title: Semantic Nutrition Estimation: Predicting Food Healthfulness from Text Descriptions
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Nutritional assessment, Food Compass Score, machine learning, text description, nutrient prediction

Summary: Accurate nutritional assessment plays a vital role in public health but is often hindered by the lack of detailed data obtainable from casual food descriptions. This paper introduces a machine learning pipeline designed to predict the comprehensive Food Compass Score 2.0 (FCS) using text descriptions of food. The method employs multi-headed neural networks that analyze hybrid feature vectors combining semantic text embeddings, lexical patterns, and domain heuristics with USDA Food and Nutrient Database for Dietary Studies (FNDDS) data. These networks estimate the necessary nutrient and food components required by the FCS algorithm. The system shows robust predictive performance, achieving a median R^2 value of 0.81 for individual nutrient predictions. Moreover, the predicted FCS values exhibit a strong correlation with published benchmarks, with Pearson’s correlation coefficient of 0.77 and a mean absolute difference of 14.0 points. The greatest prediction errors occur with ambiguous or highly processed food items. Overall, this approach effectively translates natural language food descriptions into actionable nutritional information, facilitating scalable dietary assessment for both consumer-facing applications and research purposes.
arXiv:2512.11836v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Accurate nutritional assessment is critical for public health, but existing profiling systems require detailed data often unavailable or inaccessible from colloquial text descriptions of food. This paper presents a machine learning pipeline that predicts the comprehensive Food Compass Score 2.0 (FCS) from text descriptions. Our approach uses multi-headed neural networks to process hybrid feature vectors that combine semantic text embeddings, lexical patterns, and domain heuristics, alongside USDA Food and Nutrient Database for Dietary Studies (FNDDS) data. The networks estimate the nutrient and food components necessary for the FCS algorithm. The system demonstratedstrong predictive power, achieving a median R^2 of 0.81 for individual nutrients. The predicted FCS correlated strongly with published values (Pearson's r = 0.77), with a mean absolute difference of 14.0 points. While errors were largest for ambiguous or processed foods, this methodology translates language into actionable nutritional information, enabling scalable dietary assessment for consumer applications and research.

item.title: D-STEER - Preference Alignment Techniques Learn to Behave, not to Believe -- Beneath the Surface, DPO as Steering Vector Perturbation in Activation Space
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Direct Preference Optimization, model alignment, low rank steering, logits embeddings, behavioral illusion

Summary: This paper investigates the internal mechanisms of Direct Preference Optimization (DPO), a prevalent method for aligning large language models. First, it challenges the common assumption that DPO fundamentally rewrites a model’s internal beliefs; instead, it proposes that DPO functions primarily as a low rank steering method that subtly adjusts activations along a few preference-specific directions. Second, through a simple mathematical derivation, the authors reveal that the DPO gradient depends solely on the difference between logit embeddings of preferred versus dispreferred outputs, leading to a first-order modification in the model’s final hidden layer rather than deep semantic changes. Third, the paper empirically extracts a steering vector from a DPO-tuned model, demonstrating that adding this vector to the base activations reproduces much of the model’s aligned behavior, while subtracting it largely restores the original behavior. Fourth, spectral analysis shows a rank-one dominance and entropy collapse in upper layers of the network, indicating alignment effects are concentrated within a narrow subspace. Finally, these combined findings support a "behavioral illusion" interpretation of DPO, suggesting that it primarily teaches models how to behave in an aligned manner instead of altering what they fundamentally believe or understand.
arXiv:2512.11838v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) has become a standard recipe for aligning large language models, yet it is still unclear what kind of change it actually induces inside the network. This paper argues that DPO does not rewrite a models internal beliefs; instead, it acts as a low rank steering mechanism that nudges activations along a small number of preference directions. Using a simple derivation, we show that the DPO gradient depends only on the difference between the logit embeddings of preferred and dispreferred completions, implying a first order shift in the final hidden representation rather than a deep restructuring of semantics. We then extract an empirical steering vector from a DPO tuned model and demonstrate that adding this vector to base activations reproduces most of the aligned behavior, while subtracting it nearly restores the original model. Finally, spectral analyses reveal rank-one dominance and entropy collapse in upper layers, indicating that alignment is funneled through a narrow subspace. Taken together, these results support a behavioral illusion view of DPO: it teaches models how to act aligned, not what to believe.

item.title: Large Language Models as Generalist Policies for Network Optimization
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Trailblazer, large language models, network policies, generalization, adaptive collaboration

Summary: 1. The paper introduces Trailblazer, a novel framework designed to create generalist network control policies that excel in robust network service management across diverse tasks and environments. 2. It addresses the limitations of traditional network optimization methods that rely on specialist policies using handcrafted rules or deep learning, which typically suffer from poor generalization. 3. Trailblazer leverages large language models (LLMs), pretrained on vast internet corpora, allowing access to fundamental networking principles and enabling strong generalization capabilities to unseen scenarios with minimal adaptation. 4. A core feature of Trailblazer is its network alignment scheme, which grounds the LLM in specific networking tasks, ensuring relevance and accuracy in policy formulation. 5. Additionally, it introduces an adaptive policy collaboration mechanism where simpler control tasks are offloaded from the LLM to lightweight policies, enhancing computational efficiency. 6. Extensive experiments involving simulations and real-world online deployment on Douyin (the Chinese TikTok) demonstrate that Trailblazer outperforms conventional specialist policies in cross-task and cross-environment generalization. 7. The results validate the potential of LLMs as a foundation for generalist network policies and position Trailblazer as an important step toward a generalist-driven paradigm in network control, reducing the effort required for policy design while improving adaptability and performance.
arXiv:2512.11839v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Designing control policies to ensure robust network services is essential to modern digital infrastructure. However, the dominant paradigm for network optimization relies on designing specialist policies based on handcrafted rules or deep learning models, leading to poor generalization across diverse tasks and environments. In contrast, large language models (LLMs), pretrained on Internet-scale corpora, provide a rich and unified knowledge base that encodes fundamental networking principles. Combined with their emergent abilities in generalization to unseen scenarios, LLMs offer a transformative foundation for generalist network policies that can generalize across diverse tasks and environments with minimal adaptation. In this paper, we present Trailblazer, the first systematic framework to realize such a generalist policy for networking. Trailblazer incorporates a network alignment scheme to ground the LLM in specific networking tasks, and an adaptive policy collaboration mechanism that offloads simple control cases from the LLM to a lightweight policy for computational efficiency. Through extensive simulations and large-scale real-world online evaluation on Douyin (the Chinese version of TikTok), Trailblazer, powered by a single LLM, demonstrates stronger cross-task and cross-environment generalization than conventional specialist policies. Our results validate LLMs as the foundation for generalist network policies, and position Trailblazer as the first step toward the generalist-driven paradigm that enables strong generalization with minimal efforts in policy design.

item.title: Amortized Causal Discovery with Prior-Fitted Networks
item.content:encoded:
Differentiable penalized likelihood, causal structure learning, Prior-Fitted Networks, amortized likelihood estimation, neural network accuracy

Summary: This paper addresses challenges in causal structure discovery that arise due to errors in likelihood estimation, even when large datasets are available. Traditional differentiable penalized likelihood methods optimize causal structures by maximizing likelihood values based on observed data, but their effectiveness is hampered by inaccurate likelihood estimates. The authors introduce a novel approach called Prior-Fitted Networks (PFNs) to improve the process of likelihood estimation by amortizing data-dependent likelihood calculations. By doing so, PFNs produce more reliable scores that guide causal structure learning more effectively. The method was tested extensively across a range of scenarios, including synthetic, simulated, and real-world datasets, demonstrating considerable improvements in accurately recovering causal structures as compared to standard baseline methods. Importantly, the study provides direct evidence that PFNs outperform conventional neural network-based techniques in estimating likelihoods more precisely. This work suggests that leveraging PFNs in causal discovery pipelines can enhance the robustness and accuracy of inferred causal relationships, ultimately benefiting applications that rely on precise causal modeling.
arXiv:2512.11840v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: In recent years, differentiable penalized likelihood methods have gained popularity, optimizing the causal structure by maximizing its likelihood with respect to the data. However, recent research has shown that errors in likelihood estimation, even on relatively large sample sizes, disallow the discovery of proper structures. We propose a new approach to amortized causal discovery that addresses the limitations of likelihood estimator accuracy. Our method leverages Prior-Fitted Networks (PFNs) to amortize data-dependent likelihood estimation, yielding more reliable scores for structure learning. Experiments on synthetic, simulated, and real-world datasets show significant gains in structure recovery compared to standard baselines. Furthermore, we demonstrate directly that PFNs provide more accurate likelihood estimates than conventional neural network-based approaches.

item.title: Meta-Continual Mobility Forecasting for Proactive Handover Prediction
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: short-term mobility forecasting, proactive handover, meta-continual learning, GRU predictor, edge deployment

Summary:

1. The article addresses the challenge of short-term mobility forecasting essential for proactive handover (HO) in cellular networks, where user movement is highly non-stationary due to abrupt turns and speed changes.
2. Traditional predictors often fail or drift under these dynamic conditions, causing mistimed or failed handovers.
3. The authors propose a novel lightweight meta-continual forecasting framework combining a GRU-based predictor with Reptile meta-initialization, enabling fast few-shot adaptation to changing mobility patterns.
4. An Exponentially Weighted Moving Average (EWMA) residual detector is integrated to identify drift events and trigger compact online updates selectively, improving efficiency.
5. Evaluation using GeoLife and DeepMIMO datasets shows strong zero-shot forecasting performance (4.46 m ADE, 7.79 m FDE) and improved few-shot accuracy (3.71 m ADE at 10-shot), plus a 2-3x faster recovery from abrupt drift compared to an offline GRU model.
6. When applied to downstream handover prediction, the proposed method improves F1 score to 0.83 and AUROC to 0.90 while reducing missed-HO and ping-pong events significantly.
7. The model’s small size (128k parameters) makes it suitable for deployment on edge devices within 5G and upcoming 6G networks, enabling real-time adaptability and improved network reliability.
arXiv:2512.11841v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Short-term mobility forecasting is a core requirement for proactive handover (HO) in cellular networks. Real-world mobility is highly non-stationary: abrupt turns, rapid speed changes, and unpredictable user behavior cause conventional predictors to drift, leading to mistimed or failed handovers. We propose a lightweight meta-continual forecasting framework that integrates a GRU-based predictor, Reptile meta-initialization for fast few-shot adaptation, and an EWMA residual detector that triggers compact online updates only when drift occurs. Evaluated on a reproducible GeoLife and DeepMIMO pipeline, our method achieves 4.46 m ADE and 7.79 m FDE in zero-shot settings, improves few-shot ADE to 3.71 m at 10-shot, and enables recovery from abrupt drift about 2 to 3 times faster than an offline GRU. When applied to downstream HO prediction, the approach improves F1 to 0.83 and AUROC to 0.90, with substantial reductions in missed-HO and ping-pong events. The model is lightweight (128k parameters) and suitable for edge deployment in 5G and 6G systems.

item.title: Airport Passenger Flow Forecasting via Deformable Temporal-Spectral Transformer Approach
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: passenger flow forecasting, deformable partitioning, temporal-spectral transformer, frequency-domain attention, multiscale time series

Summary: Accurate forecasting of passenger flows is vital for efficient airport operations. This paper introduces DTSFormer, a deformable temporal-spectral Transformer designed to address limitations of fixed-size patch embedding in time series forecasting. DTSFormer uses a multiscale deformable partitioning module that dynamically segments input sequences into temporal patches via a novel window function-based masking, allowing for extraction of heterogeneous trends across varying time scales. Within each scale, a frequency-domain attention mechanism captures both high-frequency volatility and low-frequency periodicity inherent in passenger flow data. Multi-frequency features are then fused in the time domain to jointly model short-term fluctuations and long-term trends. The model was evaluated on real passenger flow data from Beijing Capital International Airport, covering January 2023 to March 2024, demonstrating consistent superiority over existing forecasting methods across multiple prediction horizons. Further analyses reveal that the deformable partitioning aligns patch lengths with dominant periodic patterns and heterogeneous trends, enhancing the model's ability to capture sudden, high-frequency changes. Overall, DTSFormer effectively models complex and varied temporal dynamics in airport passenger flows, improving forecasting accuracy and robustness.
arXiv:2512.11845v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Accurate forecasting of passenger flows is critical for maintaining the efficiency and resilience of airport operations. Recent advances in patch-based Transformer models have shown strong potential in various time series forecasting tasks. However, most existing methods rely on fixed-size patch embedding, making it difficult to model the complex and heterogeneous patterns of airport passenger flows. To address this issue, this paper proposes a deformable temporal-spectral transformer named DTSFormer that integrates a multiscale deformable partitioning module and a joint temporal-spectral filtering module. Specifically, the input sequence is dynamically partitioned into multiscale temporal patches via a novel window function-based masking, enabling the extraction of heterogeneous trends across different temporal stages. Then, within each scale, a frequency-domain attention mechanism is designed to capture both high- and low-frequency components, thereby emphasizing the volatility and periodicity inherent in airport passenger flows. Finally, the resulting multi-frequency features are subsequently fused in the time domain to jointly model short-term fluctuations and long-term trends. Comprehensive experiments are conducted on real-world passenger flow data collected at Beijing Capital International Airport from January 2023 to March 2024. The results indicate that the proposed method consistently outperforms state-of-the-art forecasting models across different prediction horizons. Further analysis shows that the deformable partitioning module aligns patch lengths with dominant periods and heterogeneous trends, enabling superior capture of sudden high-frequency fluctuations.

item.title: Exploring Topological Bias in Heterogeneous Graph Neural Networks
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Heterogeneous Graph Neural Networks, topological bias, meta-weighting, PageRank, contrastive learning

Summary: This paper addresses the issue of topological bias in Heterogeneous Graph Neural Networks (HGNNs), which arises due to sparse labels in semi-supervised learning, leading to uneven performance across nodes correlated with graph structure. Unlike prior work focused on homogeneous GNNs, this study targets HGNNs where distinct meta relations exist. The authors propose applying meta-weighting to the adjacency matrix to differentiate these meta relations effectively. Using the modified adjacency matrix, they combine PageRank with node label information to construct a projection that maps nodes to values strongly associated with model performance. This projection reveals that topological bias universally exists in HGNNs, regardless of the presence of intra-type connections. To mitigate this bias, a novel debiasing structure is introduced, which utilizes the difference in the node projection values and integrates this with the original graph structure within a contrastive learning framework. Experiments conducted on three public datasets demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly improves the performance of HGNNs while successfully reducing topological bias, confirming the method’s effectiveness and general applicability in heterogeneous graph learning scenarios.
arXiv:2512.11846v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) are characterized by their capacity of processing graph-structured data. However, due to the sparsity of labels under semi-supervised learning, they have been found to exhibit biased performance on specific nodes. This kind of bias has been validated to correlate with topological structure and is considered as a bottleneck of GNNs' performance. Existing work focuses on the study of homogeneous GNNs and little attention has been given to topological bias in Heterogeneous Graph Neural Networks (HGNNs). In this work, firstly, in order to distinguish distinct meta relations, we apply meta-weighting to the adjacency matrix of a heterogeneous graph. Based on the modified adjacency matrix, we leverage PageRank along with the node label information to construct a projection. The constructed projection effectively maps nodes to values that strongly correlated with model performance when using datasets both with and without intra-type connections, which demonstrates the universal existence of topological bias in HGNNs. To handle this bias, we propose a debiasing structure based on the difference in the mapped values of nodes and use it along with the original graph structure for contrastive learning. Experiments on three public datasets verify the effectiveness of the proposed method in improving HGNNs' performance and debiasing.

item.title: Tiny Recursive Models on ARC-AGI-1: Inductive Biases, Identity Conditioning, and Test-Time Compute
item.content:encoded:
Tiny Recursive Models, Abstraction and Reasoning Corpus, test-time augmentation, recursion analysis, efficiency comparison

Summary: This technical note analyzes the Tiny Recursive Models (TRM) checkpoint on the ARC-AGI-1 benchmark to clarify the sources of its strong performance on ARC-style tasks. First, it demonstrates that test-time augmentation combined with a 1000-sample majority-vote ensembling significantly boosts performance, increasing Pass@1 accuracy by approximately 11 percentage points compared to single-pass inference. Second, an ablation study replacing task-specific puzzle identifiers with blank or random tokens results in zero accuracy, highlighting strict dependence on task conditioning. Third, an analysis of recursion trajectories reveals that most accuracy gains occur at the first recursion step, with performance saturating after only a few latent updates, indicating that TRM uses shallow recursion rather than deep reasoning. Fourth, early training experiments show that heavy data augmentation broadens the solution candidate distribution and enhances multi-sample success, emphasizing the role of training regime in observed performance. Finally, a comparison with a naive QLoRA fine-tuning of Llama 3 8B indicates that TRM's non-autoregressive design offers much higher throughput and substantially lower memory usage. Overall, these findings suggest TRM’s ARC-AGI-1 success stems from an interplay of efficiency, task-specific priors, and aggressive test-time compute rather than deep internal recursive reasoning.
arXiv:2512.11847v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Tiny Recursive Models (TRM) were proposed as a parameter-efficient alternative to large language models for solving Abstraction and Reasoning Corpus (ARC) style tasks. The original work reports strong performance and suggests that recursive latent updates enable non-trivial reasoning, but it remains unclear how much of this performance stems from architecture, test-time compute, or task-specific priors. In this technical note, we empirically analyze the ARC Prize TRM checkpoint on ARC-AGI-1 and report four behavioral findings and an efficiency comparison. First, we show that test-time augmentation and majority-vote ensembling account for a substantial fraction of reported performance: the 1000-sample voting pipeline improves Pass@1 by about 11 percentage points over single-pass canonical inference. Second, a puzzle-identity ablation reveals strict dependence on task identifiers: replacing the correct puzzle ID with a blank or random token yields zero accuracy. Third, a recursion trajectory analysis shows that most of the final accuracy is achieved at the first recursion step and that performance saturates after few latent updates, indicating shallow effective recursion. Fourth, early-stage training experiments under canonical versus heavy augmentation regimes suggest that heavy augmentation broadens the distribution of candidate solutions and improves multi-sample success. Finally, we compare TRM with a naive QLoRA fine-tune of Llama 3 8B on canonical ARC-AGI-1, finding that TRM's non-autoregressive design achieves much higher throughput and substantially lower memory usage in this setting. Overall, TRM's ARC-AGI-1 performance appears to arise from an interaction between efficiency, task-specific conditioning, and aggressive test-time compute rather than deep internal reasoning.

item.title: KV Cache Recycling to Expand Usable Context Capacity in Low Parameter LLMs
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: token recycling, key value cache, DialoGPT, inference acceleration, prompt prefix overlap

Summary: This paper investigates whether key value (KV) states used in attention mechanisms for one prompt in a small language model (LLM) can be reused to speed up inference on a similar new prompt. The approach, called token recycling, effectively increases the model's context memory by caching and reusing past activations. Using the Hugging Face framework and DialoGPT-medium, a 345 million parameter GPT-2 style model trained on Reddit conversations, the authors build a cache indexed by sentence embeddings. Cached KV pairs are reused when the new prompt is an exact prefix extension of a previously processed prompt. The paper compares baseline runs with token recycling runs in terms of latency and output fidelity, also logging how many tokens are reused from the cache. The technique requires no modifications to the model itself; cached KV pairs are saved to CPU memory, reloaded, and supplied to the generate function to continue decoding seamlessly. Experimental results show consistent speedups when prefixes overlap, without significant degradation in the model's semantic output quality. When there is no prefix overlap, the system behaves identically to the baseline, demonstrating safe fallback behavior. This method offers a practical and reproducible way to accelerate inference in certain prompt similarity scenarios.
arXiv:2512.11851v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Whether attention key value (KV) states computed for one prompt for a small LLM can be reused to accelerate inference on a new similar prompt, giving an increase to the space to its context memory using an approach called token recycling. Using a standard Hugging Face setup with DialoGPT-medium (a 345M parameter GPT-2 style decoder trained on 147M Reddit exchanges, 2005 to 2017) as the testbed, we build a cache of past activations and get entries by sentence embeddings, then reuse cached past key values when the cached prompt is an exact prefix of the new input. We compare recycled vs. baseline runs on latency and output fidelity, and log reuse depth in tokens. Reproducibility requires no model modifications, cached KVs are serialized to the CPU, reloaded, and supplied to the generate function to continue decoding from the cached prefix. In tests, we observe consistent speedups when prefix overlap exists, with no material degradation in output semantics, and when overlap is absent, behavior matches baseline.

item.title: Explainable AI for Smart Greenhouse Control: Interpretability of Temporal Fusion Transformer in the Internet of Robotic Things
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Internet of Robotic Things, Temporal Fusion Transformer, explainability, smart greenhouse, time series forecasting

Summary: This study explores the integration of the Internet of Robotic Things (IoRT) within smart greenhouse environments to enhance precision agriculture through autonomous environmental control. It addresses the challenge posed by traditional black-box time series forecasting models, which lack transparency and interpretability, key requirements for trust and regulatory adherence in smart farming. The researchers employed the Temporal Fusion Transformer (TFT) model to automate actuator settings, optimizing greenhouse management processes. To ensure the decision-making process is interpretable and trustworthy, multiple explainability techniques were applied, including model-inherent interpretation, Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations (LIME), and SHapley Additive Explanations (SHAP). These methods elucidate how sensor data—temperature, humidity, CO2 levels, light, and external climate—affect actuator control. The TFT model demonstrated a high test accuracy of 95% on a class-imbalanced dataset for the control settings automation. Additionally, the results highlight the varying contributions of each sensor to real-time adjustments in the greenhouse, promoting transparency. This enhanced interpretability facilitates adaptive fine-tuning of environmental controls, which can lead to improved crop yields and greater resource efficiency in automated greenhouse systems.
arXiv:2512.11852v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The integration of the Internet of Robotic Things (IoRT) in smart greenhouses has revolutionised precision agriculture by enabling efficient and autonomous environmental control. However, existing time series forecasting models in such setups often operate as black boxes, lacking mechanisms for explainable decision-making, which is a critical limitation when trust, transparency, and regulatory compliance are paramount in smart farming practices. This study leverages the Temporal Fusion Transformer (TFT) model to automate actuator settings for optimal greenhouse management. To enhance interpretability and trust in the model decision-making process, both local and global explanation techniques were employed using model-inherent interpretation, local interpretable model-agnostic explanations (LIME), and SHapley additive explanations (SHAP). These explainability methods provide information on how different sensor readings, such as temperature, humidity, CO2 levels, light, and outer climate, contribute to actuator control decisions in an automated greenhouse. The trained TFT model achieved a test accuracy of 95% on a class-imbalanced dataset for actuator control settings in an automated greenhouse environment. The results demonstrate the varying influence of each sensor on real-time greenhouse adjustments, ensuring transparency and enabling adaptive fine-tuning for improved crop yield and resource efficiency.

item.title: Rep Smarter, Not Harder: AI Hypertrophy Coaching with Wearable Sensors and Edge Neural Networks
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: resistance training, hypertrophy, Repetitions in Reserve, wrist-mounted IMU, real-time feedback

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge of optimizing resistance training for muscle hypertrophy by accurately assessing proximity to muscular failure, often quantified as Repetitions in Reserve (RiR). Traditional subjective methods for estimating RiR are unreliable, which can either reduce training effectiveness or lead to excessive fatigue. To solve this, the authors present a novel real-time feedback system that detects near-failure exercise states (RiR ≤ 2) using data from a single wrist-mounted Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU). Their approach involves a two-stage pipeline: a ResNet-based model segments exercise repetitions in real-time from 6-axis IMU data, followed by a classification model that uses features derived from the segmentation, convolutional features, and an LSTM-based historical context to identify near-failure effort windows. The system was trained and evaluated on a newly collected dataset from 13 participants performing preacher curls to failure, involving 631 repetitions in total. Results show the segmentation model achieved an F1 score of 0.83, and the near-failure classifier reached an F1 score of 0.82 under simulated real-time conditions at 1.6 Hz inference rate. The method's practicality was confirmed by deployment on edge hardware including a Raspberry Pi 5 (112 ms latency) and an iPhone 16 (23.5 ms latency), demonstrating feasiblity for low-latency, on-device computation. This study offers a minimal-hardware, AI-driven tool for objective, real-time training intensity feedback, potentially improving training management and hypertrophy outcomes.
arXiv:2512.11854v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Optimizing resistance training for hypertrophy requires balancing proximity to muscular failure, often quantified by Repetitions in Reserve (RiR), with fatigue management. However, subjective RiR assessment is unreliable, leading to suboptimal training stimuli or excessive fatigue. This paper introduces a novel system for real-time feedback on near-failure states (RiR $\le$ 2) during resistance exercise using only a single wrist-mounted Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU). We propose a two-stage pipeline suitable for edge deployment: first, a ResNet-based model segments repetitions from the 6-axis IMU data in real-time. Second, features derived from this segmentation, alongside direct convolutional features and historical context captured by an LSTM, are used by a classification model to identify exercise windows corresponding to near-failure states. Using a newly collected dataset from 13 diverse participants performing preacher curls to failure (631 total reps), our segmentation model achieved an F1 score of 0.83, and the near-failure classifier achieved an F1 score of 0.82 under simulated real-time evaluation conditions (1.6 Hz inference rate). Deployment on a Raspberry Pi 5 yielded an average inference latency of 112 ms, and on an iPhone 16 yielded 23.5 ms, confirming the feasibility for edge computation. This work demonstrates a practical approach for objective, real-time training intensity feedback using minimal hardware, paving the way for accessible AI-driven hypertrophy coaching tools that help users manage intensity and fatigue effectively.

item.title: Achieving Approximate Symmetry Is Exponentially Easier than Exact Symmetry
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: exact symmetry, approximate symmetry, averaging complexity, machine learning, inductive bias

Summary: 1. Enforcing exact symmetry in machine learning models provides strong inductive biases and often improves performance in scientific applications. 2. However, recent empirical findings suggest that approximate symmetry might offer greater flexibility and robustness compared to exact symmetry. 3. There has been little theoretical understanding or direct comparison between the costs involved in enforcing exact versus approximate symmetry to date. 4. This paper introduces a novel framework called averaging complexity to quantify the cost of enforcing symmetry through averaging mechanisms. 5. The main theoretical result shows an exponential separation: achieving exact symmetry requires linear averaging complexity, whereas approximate symmetry can be accomplished with only logarithmic averaging complexity. 6. This result is the first formal theoretical justification on why approximate symmetry may be more practical and preferable in machine learning model design. 7. The tools and techniques developed could have broader applications and interest for future research on exploiting symmetries in machine learning.
arXiv:2512.11855v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Enforcing exact symmetry in machine learning models often yields significant gains in scientific applications, serving as a powerful inductive bias. However, recent work suggests that relying on approximate symmetry can offer greater flexibility and robustness. Despite promising empirical evidence, there has been little theoretical understanding, and in particular, a direct comparison between exact and approximate symmetry is missing from the literature. In this paper, we initiate this study by asking: What is the cost of enforcing exact versus approximate symmetry? To address this question, we introduce averaging complexity, a framework for quantifying the cost of enforcing symmetry via averaging. Our main result is an exponential separation: under standard conditions, achieving exact symmetry requires linear averaging complexity, whereas approximate symmetry can be attained with only logarithmic averaging complexity. To the best of our knowledge, this provides the first theoretical separation of these two cases, formally justifying why approximate symmetry may be preferable in practice. Beyond this, our tools and techniques may be of independent interest for the broader study of symmetries in machine learning.

item.title: GCoDE: Efficient Device-Edge Co-Inference for GNNs via Architecture-Mapping Co-Search
item.content:encoded:
GNNs, device-edge co-inference, architecture-mapping co-design, energy prediction, inference optimization

Summary: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) are recognized as the leading method for graph learning but face significant challenges when deployed on edge devices due to high computational demands and limited resources, hindering real-time and energy-efficient inference. Device-edge co-inference is a promising approach to mitigate these limitations by distributing computation between edge devices and servers, yet existing model partitioning methods fall short for GNNs. To overcome this, the authors propose GCoDE, the first automatic framework designed for joint architecture and mapping co-design and deployment tailored to device-edge hierarchies. GCoDE innovatively treats device communication as an explicit operation, integrating architecture and mapping optimization into a unified design space. This system is aware of diverse heterogeneous hardware performance, enabling more accurate architecture efficiency evaluation. It also incorporates an energy prediction method that analyzes consumption across various GNN operations, enhancing energy assessment and guiding the identification of energy-efficient solutions. Leveraging a constraint-based random search strategy, GCoDE quickly converges to an optimal balance of accuracy and efficiency within 1.5 hours. Finally, GCoDE includes a co-inference engine for streamlined GNN deployment and execution. Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements, achieving up to 44.9 times speedup and 98.2% energy savings compared to existing methods across multiple applications and system setups.
arXiv:2512.11856v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have emerged as the state-of-the-art graph learning method. However, achieving efficient GNN inference on edge devices poses significant challenges, limiting their application in real-world edge scenarios. This is due to the high computational cost of GNNs and limited hardware resources on edge devices, which prevent GNN inference from meeting real-time and energy requirements. As an emerging paradigm, device-edge co-inference shows potential for improving inference efficiency and reducing energy consumption on edge devices. Despite its potential, research on GNN device-edge co-inference remains scarce, and our findings show that traditional model partitioning methods are ineffective for GNNs. To address this, we propose GCoDE, the first automatic framework for GNN architecture-mapping Co-design and deployment on Device-Edge hierarchies. By abstracting the device communication process into an explicit operation, GCoDE fuses the architecture and mapping scheme in a unified design space for joint optimization. Additionally, GCoDE's system performance awareness enables effective evaluation of architecture efficiency across diverse heterogeneous systems. By analyzing the energy consumption of various GNN operations, GCoDE introduces an energy prediction method that improves energy assessment accuracy and identifies energy-efficient solutions. Using a constraint-based random search strategy, GCoDE identifies the optimal solution in 1.5 hours, balancing accuracy and efficiency. Moreover, the integrated co-inference engine in GCoDE enables efficient deployment and execution of GNN co-inference. Experimental results show that GCoDE can achieve up to 44.9x speedup and 98.2% energy reduction compared to existing approaches across diverse applications and system configurations.

item.title: TopicProphet: Prophesies on Temporal Topic Trends and Stocks
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: stock prediction, topic modeling, temporal analysis, breakpoint detection, financial forecasting

Summary: The article introduces TopicProphet, a novel framework designed to improve stock market predictions by addressing inherent challenges in quantitative stock data analysis. Traditional stock prediction models struggle due to the lack of causal logic in stock data and rapid market changes limiting the availability of relevant training data. TopicProphet overcomes these issues by analyzing historical periods with similar public sentiment trends and socio-political contexts, thus providing a more nuanced and relevant dataset for model training. Unlike previous studies that focused only on identifying the impact of keywords and sentiments, this approach incorporates a sequence of advanced techniques including topic modeling, temporal analysis, breakpoint detection, and segment optimization to identify the optimal training time periods. This method ensures the model captures complex patterns linked to specific eras’ socioeconomic and political factors, yielding richer and more pertinent training data. Extensive evaluations demonstrate that TopicProphet outperforms state-of-the-art methods by effectively selecting optimal training data, leading to enhanced accuracy in forecasting financial percentage changes. Overall, this framework offers a significant step forward in stock prediction by leveraging era-specific sentiment and context rather than relying solely on raw quantitative stock data.
arXiv:2512.11857v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Stocks can't be predicted. Despite many hopes, this premise held itself true for many years due to the nature of quantitative stock data lacking causal logic along with rapid market changes hindering accumulation of significant data for training models. To undertake this matter, we propose a novel framework, TopicProphet, to analyze historical eras that share similar public sentiment trends and historical background. Our research deviates from previous studies that identified impacts of keywords and sentiments - we expand on that method by a sequence of topic modeling, temporal analysis, breakpoint detection and segment optimization to detect the optimal time period for training. This results in improving predictions by providing the model with nuanced patterns that occur from that era's socioeconomic and political status while also resolving the shortage of pertinent stock data to train on. Through extensive analysis, we conclude that TopicProphet produces improved outcomes compared to the state-of-the-art methods in capturing the optimal training data for forecasting financial percentage changes.

item.title: Adaptive Path Integral Diffusion: AdaPID
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Diffusion-based samplers, schedule selection, Harmonic PID, Gaussian Mixture target, Quality-of-Sampling (QoS)

Summary: This paper addresses diffusion-based samplers including Score Based Diffusions, Bridge Diffusions, and Path Integral Diffusions, emphasizing that their effectiveness arises from the choice of the intermediate-time schedule that governs the sampling dynamics. The authors propose a novel path-wise schedule selection framework tailored for Harmonic PID systems with time-varying stiffness. This framework exploits Piece-Wise-Constant (PWC) parametrizations combined with a hierarchical refinement approach to optimize the schedule design. A key contribution is the introduction of schedule-sensitive Quality-of-Sampling (QoS) diagnostics, which provide measurable metrics to guide schedule improvement. Under the assumption of a Gaussian Mixture (GM) target distribution, the method maintains closed-form Green function ratios and employs numerically stable, Neural-Network free oracles for predicted-state maps and score calculations, ensuring robustness and interpretability. Experimental validation in a 2D setting demonstrates that the QoS-driven PWC schedules lead to consistent improvements in early-exit fidelity, tail accuracy of the sampling distribution, the conditioning of the dynamics, and speciation timing (label-selection) when operating under fixed computational (integration) budgets. This approach provides a systematic and practical method for enhancing diffusion sampler performance without reliance on complex neural network components.
arXiv:2512.11858v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Diffusion-based samplers -- Score Based Diffusions, Bridge Diffusions and Path Integral Diffusions -- match a target at terminal time, but the real leverage comes from choosing the schedule that governs the intermediate-time dynamics. We develop a path-wise schedule -- selection gramework for Harmonic PID with a time-varying stiffness, exploiting Piece-Wise-Constant(PWC) parametrizations and a simple hierarchical refinement. We introduce schedule-sensitive Quality-of-Sampling (QoS) diagnostics. Assuming a Gaussian-Mixture (GM) target, we retain closed-form Green functions' ration and numerically stable, Neural-Network free oracles for predicted-state maps and score. Experiments in 2D show that QoS driven PWC schedules consistently improve early-exit fidelity, tail accuracy, conditioning of the dynamics, and speciation (label-selection) timing at fixed integration budgets.

item.title: Generative Stochastic Optimal Transport: Guided Harmonic Path-Integral Diffusion
item.content:encoded:
Guided Harmonic Path-Integral Diffusion, Stochastic Optimal Transport, Terminal Distribution, Gaussian-Mixture Model, Protocol Learning

Summary: This paper introduces Guided Harmonic Path-Integral Diffusion (GH-PID), a novel, linearly-solvable framework designed for guided Stochastic Optimal Transport (SOT) that integrates a hard terminal distribution with soft, application-specific path costs. GH-PID employs a low-dimensional guidance protocol to shape the ensemble of trajectories while maintaining a linear structure in the forward and backward Kolmogorov equations, allowing the optimal score to be expressed explicitly as a Green-function ratio. Notably, when terminal distributions follow a Gaussian-Mixture Model (GMM), closed-form solutions are attainable, facilitating stable sampling and enabling differentiable learning of guidance protocols under exact terminal matching conditions. The authors introduce diagnostics focused on guidance, including path cost, centerline adherence, variance flow, and drift effort, which enhance interpretability within this variational ansatz framework for empirical SOT. The methodology is demonstrated through three 2D navigation scenarios: (i) hand-crafted protocols reveal the influence of geometry and stiffness on trajectory lag, curvature, and mode evolution; (ii) single-task protocol learning optimizes a piecewise-constant centerline to minimize integrated costs; and (iii) multi-expert fusion combines competing expert trajectories and terminal distributions through a product-of-experts approach to learn a consensus guidance protocol. Across these cases, GH-PID produces trajectories that are geometry-aware and trust-aware, ensuring exact terminal distribution satisfaction while systematically reducing total path costs.
arXiv:2512.11859v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We introduce Guided Harmonic Path-Integral Diffusion (GH-PID), a linearly-solvable framework for guided Stochastic Optimal Transport (SOT) with a hard terminal distribution and soft, application-driven path costs. A low-dimensional guidance protocol shapes the trajectory ensemble while preserving analytic structure: the forward and backward Kolmogorov equations remain linear, the optimal score admits an explicit Green-function ratio, and Gaussian-Mixture Model (GMM) terminal laws yield closed-form expressions. This enables stable sampling and differentiable protocol learning under exact terminal matching. We develop guidance-centric diagnostics -- path cost, centerline adherence, variance flow, and drift effort -- that make GH-PID an interpretable variational ansatz for empirical SOT. Three navigation scenarios illustrated in 2D: (i) Case A: hand-crafted protocols revealing how geometry and stiffness shape lag, curvature effects, and mode evolution; (ii) Case B: single-task protocol learning, where a PWC centerline is optimized to minimize integrated cost; (iii) Case C: multi-expert fusion, in which a commander reconciles competing expert/teacher trajectories and terminal beliefs through an exact product-of-experts law and learns a consensus protocol. Across all settings, GH-PID generates geometry-aware, trust-aware trajectories that satisfy the prescribed terminal distribution while systematically reducing integrated cost.

item.title: An Operator-Consistent Graph Neural Network for Learning Diffusion Dynamics on Irregular Meshes
item.content:encoded:
PDE, graph neural network, operator consistency, irregular meshes, physics-informed learning

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge of solving partial differential equations (PDEs) on irregular domains where classical numerical methods often become unstable. The authors propose an Operator-Consistent Graph Neural Network combined with Physics-Informed Neural Networks (OCGNN-PINN) designed specifically to approximate PDE evolution under physics constraints. The core innovation lies in coupling node-edge message passing with a consistency loss that enforces the gradient-divergence relation via the graph incidence matrix. This approach ensures that the dynamics at nodes and edges remain structurally coupled over time, enhancing temporal stability. The model is tested on diffusion processes occurring on physically evolving meshes as well as real-world scanned surfaces, which represent irregular domains. Results indicate that OCGNN-PINN improves both prediction accuracy and temporal stability compared to standard graph convolutional networks and multilayer perceptron baselines. Furthermore, it approaches the performance of Crank-Nicolson numerical solvers, a classical method known for stability on unstructured meshes. This work demonstrates the effectiveness of embedding operator consistency and physics-informed constraints in graph neural networks for complex multiphysics simulations on irregular geometries.
arXiv:2512.11860v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Classical numerical methods solve partial differential equations (PDEs) efficiently on regular meshes, but many of them become unstable on irregular domains. In practice, multiphysics interactions such as diffusion, damage, and healing often take place on irregular meshes. We develop an operator-consistent graph neural network (OCGNN-PINN) that approximates PDE evolution under physics-informed constraints. It couples node-edge message passing with a consistency loss enforcing the gradient-divergence relation through the graph incidence matrix, ensuring that discrete node and edge dynamics remain structurally coupled during temporal rollout. We evaluate the model on diffusion processes over physically driven evolving meshes and real-world scanned surfaces. The results show improved temporal stability and prediction accuracy compared with graph convolutional and multilayer perceptron baselines, approaching the performance of Crank-Nicolson solvers on unstructured domains.

item.title: Hierarchical Task Offloading and Trajectory Optimization in Low-Altitude Intelligent Networks Via Auction and Diffusion-based MARL
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: low-altitude intelligent networks, UAV trajectory planning, task offloading, multi-agent reinforcement learning, energy efficiency

Summary: This paper addresses the challenges in low-altitude intelligent networks (LAINs) that combine unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), aerial base stations, and terrestrial base stations to provide low-latency and energy-efficient edge intelligence in dynamic, infrastructure-limited environments. The main challenges include limited UAV energy, stochastic task arrivals, and heterogeneous computing resources. To overcome these, the authors propose an integrated air-ground collaborative network and formulate a complex time-dependent integer nonlinear programming problem to jointly optimize UAV trajectory planning and task offloading decisions. Due to temporal dependencies among variables, the problem is difficult to solve directly. The authors design a hierarchical learning framework operating on two timescales: a large timescale using a Vickrey-Clarke-Groves auction mechanism for energy-aware and incentive-compatible trajectory assignment, and a small timescale employing diffusion-heterogeneous-agent proximal policy optimization, a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning algorithm that integrates latent diffusion models into actor networks. This enables each UAV to sample and refine actions based on observation-conditioned denoising, improving adaptability and policy diversity. Extensive simulations demonstrate that the proposed framework outperforms existing baselines in terms of energy efficiency, task success rate, and convergence performance, highlighting its effectiveness in managing LAINs.
arXiv:2512.11862v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The low-altitude intelligent networks (LAINs) emerge as a promising architecture for delivering low-latency and energy-efficient edge intelligence in dynamic and infrastructure-limited environments. By integrating unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), aerial base stations, and terrestrial base stations, LAINs can support mission-critical applications such as disaster response, environmental monitoring, and real-time sensing. However, these systems face key challenges, including energy-constrained UAVs, stochastic task arrivals, and heterogeneous computing resources. To address these issues, we propose an integrated air-ground collaborative network and formulate a time-dependent integer nonlinear programming problem that jointly optimizes UAV trajectory planning and task offloading decisions. The problem is challenging to solve due to temporal coupling among decision variables. Therefore, we design a hierarchical learning framework with two timescales. At the large timescale, a Vickrey-Clarke-Groves auction mechanism enables the energy-aware and incentive-compatible trajectory assignment. At the small timescale, we propose the diffusion-heterogeneous-agent proximal policy optimization, a generative multi-agent reinforcement learning algorithm that embeds latent diffusion models into actor networks. Each UAV samples actions from a Gaussian prior and refines them via observation-conditioned denoising, enhancing adaptability and policy diversity. Extensive simulations show that our framework outperforms baselines in energy efficiency, task success rate, and convergence performance.

item.title: Phase transitions reveal hierarchical structure in deep neural networks
item.content:encoded:
phase transitions, saddle points, mode connectivity, loss landscape, deep neural networks

Summary:

Training deep neural networks (DNNs) involves navigating a high-dimensional, non-convex loss landscape to find good minima, but the underlying training dynamics remain not fully understood. This work addresses three key phenomena observed during training: phase transitions similar to those in statistical physics, the prevalence of saddle points, and the concept of mode connectivity relevant for merging models. The authors propose a unified explanatory framework based on the geometry of the loss and error landscapes, analytically demonstrating that phase transitions in DNN learning are driven by saddle points in these landscapes. Leveraging this insight, they introduce a simple, fast algorithm that employs the L2 regularizer as a probe to explore error landscape geometry. Applying this method to DNNs trained on the MNIST dataset, they efficiently identify paths connecting global minima, thereby confirming mode connectivity in practice. Further numerical experiments show that saddle points cause transitions between models that represent different digit classes. Overall, the study connects key training phenomena to the geometric structure of loss landscapes, revealing a hierarchy of accuracy basins analogous to phases found in statistical physics. This contributes to a deeper theoretical understanding of DNN training dynamics and provides practical tools for model analysis.
arXiv:2512.11866v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Training Deep Neural Networks relies on the model converging on a high-dimensional, non-convex loss landscape toward a good minimum. Yet, much of the phenomenology of training remains ill understood. We focus on three seemingly disparate observations: the occurrence of phase transitions reminiscent of statistical physics, the ubiquity of saddle points, and phenomenon of mode connectivity relevant for model merging. We unify these within a single explanatory framework, the geometry of the loss and error landscapes. We analytically show that phase transitions in DNN learning are governed by saddle points in the loss landscape. Building on this insight, we introduce a simple, fast, and easy to implement algorithm that uses the L2 regularizer as a tool to probe the geometry of error landscapes. We apply it to confirm mode connectivity in DNNs trained on the MNIST dataset by efficiently finding paths that connect global minima. We then show numerically that saddle points induce transitions between models that encode distinct digit classes. Our work establishes the geometric origin of key training phenomena in DNNs and reveals a hierarchy of accuracy basins analogous to phases in statistical physics.

item.title: On the Dangers of Bootstrapping Generation for Continual Learning and Beyond
item.content:encoded:
synthetic data, continual learning, generative models, distribution drift, maximum likelihood estimation

Summary: The paper examines the impact of repeatedly training machine learning models on synthetically generated data, a practice increasingly common for augmenting datasets. It highlights concerns about distribution drift and performance degradation resulting from dataset contamination due to synthetic data bootstrapping. By framing the issue within the context of continual learning, the study draws parallels to Generative Experience Replay (GER) methods. A statistical analysis demonstrates that synthetic data introduces considerable bias and variance into training objectives, undermining the reliability of maximum likelihood estimation techniques. Empirical results indicate that popular generative models experience collapse when subjected to repeated training on synthetic datasets. The research quantifies this degradation and reveals that even advanced GER techniques fail to preserve latent space alignment during continual learning. These findings raise significant issues regarding the long-term use of synthetic data for training, emphasizing potential pitfalls for performance and model stability. The study calls for cautious adoption of synthetic data in continual learning frameworks and suggests a need for improved strategies to mitigate bias, variance, and distribution drift induced by synthetic training samples.
arXiv:2512.11867v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The use of synthetically generated data for training models is becoming a common practice. While generated data can augment the training data, repeated training on synthetic data raises concerns about distribution drift and degradation of performance due to contamination of the dataset. We investigate the consequences of this bootstrapping process through the lens of continual learning, drawing a connection to Generative Experience Replay (GER) methods. We present a statistical analysis showing that synthetic data introduces significant bias and variance into training objectives, weakening the reliability of maximum likelihood estimation. We provide empirical evidence showing that popular generative models collapse under repeated training with synthetic data. We quantify this degradation and show that state-of-the-art GER methods fail to maintain alignment in the latent space. Our findings raise critical concerns about the use of synthetic data in continual learning.

item.title: Data-Driven Global Sensitivity Analysis for Engineering Design Based on Individual Conditional Expectations
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Explainable machine learning, Partial Dependence Plots, Individual Conditional Expectation, Global sensitivity, Feature importance

Summary: 1. Explainable machine learning is crucial in engineering fields such as aerospace, where understanding variable influence on predictions is essential. 2. Partial Dependence Plots (PDPs) are commonly used to interpret black-box models by showing average effects of input variables; however, PDPs can be misleading in the presence of strong feature interactions because averaging masks interaction effects. 3. The authors propose a new global sensitivity metric based on Individual Conditional Expectation (ICE) curves, capturing the expected feature importance and its variability to better reflect interaction effects. 4. A mathematical proof is presented showing that the PDP-based sensitivity metric is a lower bound of the ICE-based metric under truncated orthogonal polynomial expansions. 5. An ICE-based correlation value is also introduced to quantify interaction-driven changes in input-output relationships. 6. The methodology is tested on three cases: a 5-variable analytical function, a 5-variable wind-turbine fatigue problem, and a 9-variable airfoil aerodynamics problem. 7. ICE-based sensitivity is compared with PDP, SHAP, and Sobol' indices, demonstrating richer insights into feature importance and complementing visual interpretations provided by other methods. 8. Overall, the ICE-based approach provides a more nuanced understanding of input influences, especially when interactions are significant in complex engineering models.
arXiv:2512.11946v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Explainable machine learning techniques have gained increasing attention in engineering applications, especially in aerospace design and analysis, where understanding how input variables influence data-driven models is essential. Partial Dependence Plots (PDPs) are widely used for interpreting black-box models by showing the average effect of an input variable on the prediction. However, their global sensitivity metric can be misleading when strong interactions are present, as averaging tends to obscure interaction effects. To address this limitation, we propose a global sensitivity metric based on Individual Conditional Expectation (ICE) curves. The method computes the expected feature importance across ICE curves, along with their standard deviation, to more effectively capture the influence of interactions. We provide a mathematical proof demonstrating that the PDP-based sensitivity is a lower bound of the proposed ICE-based metric under truncated orthogonal polynomial expansion. In addition, we introduce an ICE-based correlation value to quantify how interactions modify the relationship between inputs and the output. Comparative evaluations were performed on three cases: a 5-variable analytical function, a 5-variable wind-turbine fatigue problem, and a 9-variable airfoil aerodynamics case, where ICE-based sensitivity was benchmarked against PDP, SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP), and Sobol' indices. The results show that ICE-based feature importance provides richer insights than the traditional PDP-based approach, while visual interpretations from PDP, ICE, and SHAP complement one another by offering multiple perspectives.

item.title: Neural Chameleons: Language Models Can Learn to Hide Their Thoughts from Unseen Activation Monitors
item.content:encoded:
Activation monitoring, Neural Chameleons, model evasion, misalignment threat, robustness
